aberrant.definition: markedly different from an accepted norm
aberrant.example: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.

aberration.definition: a deviation from what is normal or expected
aberration.example: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

abstain.definition: choose not to consume or take part in (particularly something enjoyable)
abstain.example: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar--even chocolate.

abstruse.example: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

accolade.definition: an award or praise granted as a special honor
accolade.example: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

acerbic.example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

acrimony.example: The acrimonious dispute between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

adamant.example: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

admonish.definition: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding
admonish.example: Before the concert began, security personel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.

admonitory.definition: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective
admonitory.example: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.

aesthete.definition: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
aesthete.example: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

aesthetic.definition: a set of principles underlying and guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic
aesthetic.example: The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph to be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.

amalgam.example: The band's music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.

ambiguous.definition: open to more than one interpretation
ambiguous.example: The coach told his team, "Move towards that side of the field"; because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.

ambivalent.definition: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
ambivalent.example: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

ameliorate.example: Three Cups of Tea tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.

amenable.example: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

amorphous.example: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

anomalous.example: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous--average temps should return to average, they believe.

anomaly.definition: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
anomaly.example: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

antipathy.definition: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
antipathy.example: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

antithetical.definition: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
antithetical.example: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the disattachment Buddhism preaches.

apathetic.definition: marked by a lack of interest
apathetic.example: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

apathy.definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
apathy.example: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.

apocryphal.example: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

appease.definition: pacify by acceding to the demands of
appease.example: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

arbitrary.definition: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.example: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.

arcane.example: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to the join the fraterntiy must learn.

arduous.definition: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
arduous.example: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

artful.example: Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.

ascetic.example: Historically, ascetics like Ghandi are often considered wise men partially because of their restraint.

askance.definition: with a look of suspicion or disapproval

audacious.definition: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
audacious.example: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

audacity.example: She surprised her colleagues by having the audacity to publically criticize the findings of an distinguished scientist.

auspicious.example: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike's road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

austere.example: The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.

avaricious.example: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust--sins of excess--it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

banal.definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
banal.example: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from bordeom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.

banality.example: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

belie.definition: to give a false representation to; misrepresent
belie.example: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.

belligerent.definition: characteristic of one eager to fight
belligerent.example: Tom said that he was arguing the matter purely for philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.

betray.definition: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally
betray.example: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

blatant.definition: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
blatant.example: Allen was often punished in school for blatantly disrespecting teachers.

bolster.example: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

brazen.example: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

bucolic.definition: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country
bucolic.example: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

bumbling.definition: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands
bumbling.example: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.

burgeon.example: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the U.S. real estate bubble of 2008.

calumny.definition: making of a false statement meant to injure a person"s reputation
calumny.example: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist- high.

capricious.definition: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
capricious.example: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

castigate.example: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

censure.example: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

chastise.example: Though chastised for his wanton abuse of the pantry, Lawrence shrugged off his mother's harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

chortle.example: Walking past the bar, I could hear happy, chortling people and the blast of horns from a jazz band.

circumscribe.example: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.

circumvent.definition: cleverly find a way out of one's duties or obligations
circumvent.example: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

commensurate.definition: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
commensurate.example: The convicted felon's life sentence was commensurate to the heinousness of his crime.

concede.definition: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another
concede.example: The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory they had previously conquered.

confound.example: Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.

conspicuous.definition: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
conspicuous.example: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad--not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.

constituent.example: The constituents of the metal alloy are nickle, copper, and tin.

construe.example: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

contingent.definition: possible but not certain to occur
contingent.example: Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.

contrition.definition: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
contrition.example: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board-- often get shortened sentences.

contrive.definition: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
contrive.example: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

copious.example: In midsummer, there are copious popiscle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

craven.example: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

cryptic.example: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

culminate.definition: reach the highest or most decisive point
culminate.example: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

culpability.example: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

decorous.definition: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
decorous.example: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

decorum.example: You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell, said the judge to the prosecutor.

deferential.example: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

deleterious.example: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

delineate.example: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stroke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.

demur.example: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they going skiing in the Alps.

denigrate.definition: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of
denigrate.example: Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.

denote.definition: be a sign or indication of; have as a meaning
denote.example: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes "stop" to all motorists in America.

derivative.definition: (or a creative product, e.g. music, writing, etc.) not original but drawing on the
derivative.example: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.

derive.definition: reason by deduction; establish by deduction
derive.example: From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue: Sheila was not alone in the room at the time of the murder.

dictatorial.definition: expecting unquestioning obedience; characteristic of an absolute ruler
dictatorial.example: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.

didactic.example: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Illyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

diffident.example: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

dilatory.example: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

dilettante.definition: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends

disaffected.example: After watching his superior take rations from the soliders, he quickly became disaffected and rebeled.

discrete.definition: constituting a separate entity or part
discrete.example: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.

disinterested.example: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

dispassionate.definition: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.example: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

disseminate.example: Before the effects of anaethesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

dogmatic.definition: highly opinionated, not accepting that your belief may not be correct
dogmatic.example: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

duress.example: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

eclectic.definition: comprised of a variety of styles
eclectic.example: Joey was known for his eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next "air conducting" along to Beethoven's 9th symphony.

economical.example: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

edifying.definition: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
edifying.example: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

efficacious.example: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

egregious.definition: standing out in negative way; shockingly bad
egregious.example: The dictator's abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders asked that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

elicit.example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

elucidate.definition: make clearer and easier to understand
elucidate.example: Youtube is great place to learn just about anything--an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.

eminent.definition: standing above others in quality or position
eminent.example: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.

enervate.example: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he'd spent the day sightseeing.

engender.example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

entrenched.example: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

ephemeral.example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

equivocal.example: The findings of the study were equivocal--the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

eradicate.example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

erudite.example: Before the Internet, the library was typically were you would find erudite readers.

eschew.definition: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
eschew.example: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

esoteric.definition: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pasttime.

espouse.definition: to adopt or support an idea or cause
espouse.example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.

exacerbate.example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

exacting.example: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

exalt.example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

exonerate.definition: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
exonerate.example: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.

expound.definition: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth
expound.example: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

extant.example: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

fallacious.definition: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
fallacious.example: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.

fastidious.example: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

flux.definition: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
flux.example: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

foment.definition: try to stir up public opinion
foment.example: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

forlorn.example: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

forthcoming.definition: at ease in talking to others
forthcoming.example: As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.

fortuitous.definition: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause
fortuitous.example: While the real objects are vastly different sizes in space, the sun and the moon seem to have the same fortuitous size in the sky.

frivolous.definition: not serious in content or attitude or behavior
frivolous.example: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

frugal.definition: not spending much money (but spending wisely)
frugal.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

frustrate.definition: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
frustrate.example: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.

furtive.definition: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
furtive.example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

gainsay.definition: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
gainsay.example: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

gall.definition: feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will
gall.example: In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.

galvanize.definition: to excite or inspire (someone) to action
galvanize.example: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, "Go Kyle"; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

garrulous.example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

gauche.example: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

germane.example: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

glut.example: In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

gossamer.definition: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
gossamer.example: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

gregarious.definition: to be likely to socialize with others
gregarious.example: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.

guileless.example: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

hackneyed.definition: lacking significance through having been overused

haphazard.definition: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
haphazard.example: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.

harangue.definition: to deliver a long pompous speech or tirade
harangue.example: Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness and lack of initiative, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.

harried.definition: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
harried.example: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

haughty.definition: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as
haughty.example: The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant his own.

hegemony.example: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

heretic.definition: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)
heretic.example: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.

iconoclast.definition: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
iconoclast.example: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.

iconoclastic.example: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

idiosyncrasy.definition: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
idiosyncrasy.example: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.

ignoble.example: In the 1920s, the World Series was rigged--an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

ignominious.definition: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.example: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

immutable.example: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

impartial.definition: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
impartial.example: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

impertinent.definition: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold

implacable.definition: incapable of making less angry or hostile
implacable.example: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.

implausible.definition: describing a statement that is not believable
implausible.example: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.

imprudent.example: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

impudent.example: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

incisive.definition: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
incisive.example: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

incongruous.definition: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness
incongruous.example: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.

incorrigible.example: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

indecorous.definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite
indecorous.example: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

indifference.definition: the trait of seeming not to care
indifference.example: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.

inexorable.example: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

ingenuous.example: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

ingratiate.definition: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
ingratiate.example: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.

inimical.example: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

innocuous.definition: harmless and doesn"t produce any ill effects
innocuous.example: Everyone found Nancy's banter innocuous--except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

inscrutable.example: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

insidious.definition: working in a subtle but destructive way
insidious.example: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

insolent.example: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

intimate.example: At first Manfred's teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy's precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.

intransigent.definition: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action
intransigent.example: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.

intrepid.example: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimate leads to his downfall.

inveterate.example: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

involved.example: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate's eyes glazed over.

irrevocable.definition: incapable of being retracted or revoked
irrevocable.example: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

itinerant.definition: traveling from place to place to work
itinerant.example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.

jingoism.example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

jovial.definition: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
jovial.example: The political candidate and his supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

jubilant.definition: full of high-spirited delight because of triumph or success
jubilant.example: My hardwork paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.

juxtapose.example: The meaning of her paintings comes from a classical style which juxtaposes modern themes.

laconic.definition: one who says very few words
laconic.example: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative--and not very hunky.

lambast.example: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

languid.definition: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
languid.example: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

largess.example: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

laudable.example: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

lionize.example: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

magnanimous.definition: noble and generous in spirit, especially towards a rival or someone less
magnanimous.example: He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complementary and in victory he was magnanimous.

maintain.example: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

maladroit.example: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

maverick.definition: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
maverick.example: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

mawkish.definition: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting
mawkish.example: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illnesses by the end of the movie.

mendacity.example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

mercurial.definition: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood
mercurial.example: The fact that Ella's moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships--it didn't help that she lived in Chicago.

meticulous.definition: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
meticulous.example: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

misconstrue.example: The politician never trusted journalists because he though that they misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

mitigate.definition: lessen the severity of an offense
mitigate.example: If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.

mollify.definition: to make someone angry less angry; placate
mollify.example: In the morning, Harriat was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he had his cup of coffee.

mundane.example: Though we think of the pope as someone always dealing in holy matters, he is also concerned with mundane events, such as deciding when to set his alarm each morning.

munificent.example: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

myopic.example: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.

myriad.example: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

negligible.definition: so small as to be meaningless; insignificant
negligible.example: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.

nonplussed.definition: unsure how to act or respond
nonplussed.example: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

nuance.definition: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.example: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advice us and help.

obscure.example: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.

obsequious.definition: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner; attempting to win favor from
obsequious.example: The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.

opaque.example: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.

opulence.definition: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opulence.example: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive cavier.

ostentatious.definition: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar
ostentatious.example: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.

ostracize.definition: exclude from a community or group
ostracize.example: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

panache.example: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat, a cane, and a long cape covered in sequins.

parochial.definition: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook

parsimonious.example: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

pedantic.definition: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects
pedantic.example: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.

pedestrian.example: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

pejorative.definition: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.example: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

perfidy.definition: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust
perfidy.example: The lowest circles in Dante's Inferno were for those who had practiced perfidy, and among these, the very lowest was for those, such as Judas, who had been treacherous to one of their benefactors.

pernicious.definition: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way
pernicious.example: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

petulant.example: When Ed first met Ruth, he didn't realize she was so petulant, but now that they are three months into their relationship, Ed feels a day doesn't go by in which she isn't whining about some minor issue.

placate.definition: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
placate.example: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

platitude.example: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

poignant.example: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet,  in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken familes agree to end their feud once and for all.

polemic.definition: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.example: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

posit.example: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

pragmatic.definition: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
pragmatic.example: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.

precipitous.definition: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
precipitous.example: He was expecting a precipitous rise in the value of a "hot" tech stock, so he was disappointed when it only inched up a dollar or two each day.

preclude.definition: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
preclude.example: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

precocious.definition: characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity
precocious.example: Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.

predilection.example: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

prescience.definition: the power to foresee the future
prescience.example: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

prevaricate.definition: to speak in an evasive way
prevaricate.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".

prodigal.example: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception--most live decadent lives.

prodigious.definition: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
prodigious.example: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

profligate.definition: someone who spends money recklessly or wastefully
profligate.example: Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.

prolific.example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

propitious.definition: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
propitious.example: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.

provincial.definition: characteristic of the a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated
provincial.example: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.

pundit.definition: someone who has been admitted to membership in a scholarly field
pundit.example: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.

qualify.definition: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)
qualify.example: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding that he didn't like the weather as much as the weather in Los Angeles.

querulous.example: The querulous old woman was begining to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

quotidian.definition: found in the ordinary course of events
quotidian.example: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.

ravenous.definition: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities
ravenous.example: John didn't each much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surpring that he has a ravenous appetite.

rebuke.example: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

reconcile.example: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

recondite.definition: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or
recondite.example: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

refractory.definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
refractory.example: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory Kindgergarteners who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.

refute.definition: prove to be false or incorrect
refute.example: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.

reproach.example: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

repudiate.example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

rescind.example: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

restive.example: The crowd grew restive as the comedian's opening jokes fell flat.

resurgent.definition: rising again as to new life and vigor
resurgent.example: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.

reticent.definition: reluctant to draw attention to yourself; temperamentally disinclined to talk
reticent.example: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

reverent.definition: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
reverent.example: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

rudimentary.definition: being in the earliest stages of development; being or involving basic facts or
rudimentary.example: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.

rustic.definition: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial
rustic.example: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

sanction.definition: a legal penalty for a forbidden action
sanction.example: International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.

scrupulous.definition: having a sense of right and wrong; principled
scrupulous.example: Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.

soporific.example: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

specious.example: He made a career out of specious arguments and fictional lab results, but lost his job and reputation when his lies were exposed by an article in The New York Times.

sporadic.definition: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances
sporadic.example: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation eminating from deep space.

spurious.example: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

staunch.definition: firm and dependable especially in loyalty
staunch.example: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement, Todd now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.

stringent.definition: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
stringent.example: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

subsume.definition: consider (an instance of something) as part of a general rule or principle
subsume.example: Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.

subversive.definition: in opposition to a civil authority or government

sullen.example: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

superfluous.definition: more than is needed, desired, or required
superfluous.example: Everything in this closet is superfluous and can be given to charity.

supplant.definition: take the place or move into the position of
supplant.example: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.

sycophant.definition: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage
sycophant.example: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

taciturn.example: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

tantamount.example: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

temperance.example: Welles wasn't known for his temperance--he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

tempered.example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

tenacious.example: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

timorous.definition: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
timorous.example: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

torpor.definition: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
torpor.example: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

tortuous.definition: marked by repeated turns and bends; not straightforward
tortuous.example: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.

tractable.definition: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or
tractable.example: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

transient.example: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

travesty.definition: an absurd presentation of something; a mockery
travesty.example: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.

treacherous.example: The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across, and so I think I will stay put right here.

trite.definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
trite.example: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.

truncate.example: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

undermine.definition: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
undermine.example: The student undermined the teacher's authority by questioning the teacher's judgment on numerous occasions.

underscore.example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

unequivocal.definition: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding; having only one meaning or
unequivocal.example: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was cafeful to make his position completely unequivocal.

unscrupulous.example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

upbraid.example: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"--in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

vacillate.definition: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of
vacillate.example: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

vehement.definition: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
vehement.example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

venality.definition: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
venality.example: Even some of the most sacrosanct sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

venerate.example: The professor, despite his soporific lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

veracious.example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak  will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

vilify.example: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

vindicate.definition: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
vindicate.example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

vociferous.definition: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
vociferous.example: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around an look at them angrily.

volubility.definition: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
volubility.example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

wanting.example: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

winsome.definition: charming in a childlike or naive way
winsome.example: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

aboveboard.example: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard -- some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.

abysmal.example: Coach Ramsey took his newest player off the field after watching a few painful minutes of her abysmal performance.

acme.example: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

advocate.definition: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea

affable.example: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn't around other people.

affluent.example: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

altruism.definition: the quality of unselfish concern for the welfare of others
altruism.example: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.

amiable.example: Amy's name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.

amply.example: The boat was amply supplied for its year at sea--no man would go hungry or thirst.

amuck.definition: in a frenzied or uncontrolled state
amuck.example: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amuck, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.

analogous.definition: similar in some respects but otherwise different
analogous.example: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.

animosity.example: The governor's animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor's first term.

antedated.example: Harry was so unknowledgable that he was unaware the Egyptian pharaohs antedated the American Revolution.

antiquated.definition: old-fashioned; belonging to an earlier period in time
antiquated.example: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.

apex.example: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the secondary education system.

aphorism.definition: a short instructive saying about a general truth
aphorism.example: Nietzsche was known for using aphorisms, sometimes encapsulating a complex philosophical thought in a mere sentence.

aphoristic.definition: something that is a concise and instructive of a general truth or principle
aphoristic.example: Sometimes I can't stand Nathan because he tries to impress everyone by being aphoristic, but he just states the obvious.

appreciable.definition: large enough to be noticed (usu. refers to an amount)
appreciable.example: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.

apprehension.example: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.

archaic.definition: so old as to appear to belong to a different period
archaic.example: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice--needless to say, she didn't have many friends.

ascendancy.definition: the state that exists when one person or group has power over another
ascendancy.example: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear--they have a decade of championships behind them.

ascribe.example: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Illiad to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.

assail.example: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.

assuage.example: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in line.

augment.example: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

autonomously.definition: In an autonomous or self-governing manner.
autonomously.example: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.

avarice.definition: greed (one of the seven deadly sins)
avarice.example: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.

avert.example: The struggling videogame company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankrupcy.

avid.definition: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
avid.example: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.

badger.example: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.

balk.example: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.

banish.definition: expel from a community, residence, or location; drive away
banish.example: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.

beatific.example: Often we imagine all monks to wear the beatific smile of the Buddha, but, like any of us, a monk can have a bad day and not look very happy.

becoming.example: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.

begrudge.example: We never begrudge money spent on ourselves.

behooves.definition: to be one's duty or obligation

belittle.definition: lessen the importance, dignity, or reputation of
belittle.example: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.

bellicose.example: Known for their bellicose ways, the Spartans were once the most feared people from Peloponnesus to Persia.

benign.definition: (medicine) not dangerous to health; not recurrent or progressive
benign.example: The tumor located in your ear lobe seems to be benign and should not cause you any trouble.

besiege.definition: harass, as with questions or requests; cause to feel distressed or worried
besiege.example: After discovering a priceless artifact in her backyard, Jane was besieged by phone calls, emails, and reporters all trying to buy, hold or see the rare piece of history.

besmirch.definition: damage the good name and reputation of someone
besmirch.example: The prince's distasteful choice of words besmirched not only his own name, but the reputation of the entire royal family.

bleak.definition: having a depressing or gloomy outlook
bleak.example: Unremitting overcast skies tend to lead people to create bleak literature and lugubrious music -- compare England's band Radiohead to any band from Southern California.

boon.example: He was a boon companion to many, and will be sadly missed.

boorish.definition: ill-mannered and coarse or contemptible in behavior or appearance
boorish.example: Bukowski was known for being a boorish drunk and alienating close friends and family.

brusquely.example: Not one for social pleasantries, the Chief of Staff would brusquely ask his subordinates anything he wanted, even coffee.

buck.example: The profits at our firm bucked the general downturn that effected the real estate industry.

buttress.example: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

cadaverous.example: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that they appear cadaverous.

candid.definition: a straightforward and honest look at something
candid.example: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.

candidness.definition: the quality of being honest and straightforward in attitude and speech
candidness.example: Although I was unhappy that the relationship ended, I appreciated her candidness about why she was ready to move on from the relationship.

cardinal.example: Most cultures consider gambling a cardinal sin and thus have outlawed its practice.

carping.example: What seemed like incessant nagging and carping about my behavior from my mother turned out to be wise and useful advice that has served me well.

catalyst.definition: something that speeds up an event
catalyst.example: Rosa Park's refusal to give up her bus seat acted as a catalyst for the Civil Rights Movement, setting into motion historic changes for African-Americans.

cavalier.definition: given to haughty disregard of others
cavalier.example: Percy dismissed the issue with a cavalier wave of his hand.

censor.definition: to examine and remove objectionable material
censor.example: Every fall, high school English teachers are inundated by requests to censor their curriculum by removing The Catcher in the Rye and Scarlet Letter from their reading lists.

cerebral.definition: involving intelligence rather than emotions or instinct
cerebral.example: A cerebral analysis of most pop music finds it to be simple and childish, but that ignores the point--the music's effect on the listener.

champion.definition: protect or fight for as a champion
champion.example: Martin Luther King Jr. championed civil rights fiercely throughout his short life.

chauvinist.definition: a person who believes in the superiority of their group
chauvinist.example: The chauvinist lives on both sides of the political spectrum, outright shunning anybody whose ideas are not consistent with his own.

check.definition: the condition of being held back or limited
check.example: When government abuses are not kept in check, that government is likely to become autocratic.

checkered.definition: one that is marked by disreputable happenings
checkered.example: One by one, the presidential candidates dropped out of the race, their respective checkered pasts-- from embezzlement to infidelity--sabotaging their campaigns.

chivalrous.definition: being attentive to women like an ideal knight
chivalrous.example: Marco's chivalrous ways, like opening doors and pulling out chairs, was much appreciated by his date.

clemency.definition: leniency and compassion shown toward offenders by a person or agency charged with
clemency.example: In the final moments of the trial, during his closing speech, Phillips was nearly begging the judge for clemency.

coalesce.definition: fuse or cause to grow together
coalesce.example: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.

cogent.example: A cogent argument will change the minds of even the most skeptical audience.

cohesive.definition: well integrated, forming a united whole
cohesive.example: A well-written, cohesive essay will keep on topic at all times, never losing sight of the main argument.

collusion.example: Many have argued that Lee Harvey Oswald, JFK's assassin, was in collusion with other criminals; others maintain that Oswald was a lone gunman.

colossal.definition: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
colossal.example: Few appreciate the colossal scale of the sun: if hollow, it could contain a million Earths.

commendable.example: The efforts of the firefighters running into the burning building were commendable.

complacent.definition: contented to a fault with oneself or one's actions
complacent.example: After the water polo team won their sixth championship, they became complacent and didn't even make it to the playoffs the next year.

complementary.definition: enhancing each other's qualities (for two things or more).
complementary.example: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.

compound.definition: make more intense, stronger, or more marked
compound.example: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.

conducive.definition: making a situation or outcome more likely to happen
conducive.example: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.

conniving.definition: taking part in immoral and unethical plots
conniving.example: The queen was so conniving that, with the help of the prince, she tried to overthrow the king.

consecrate.definition: to make holy or set apart for a high purpose
consecrate.example: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.

constraint.example: He found pop music a constraint on his ability to learn and preferred to listen to classical musical while studying.

consummate.definition: to make perfect and complete in every respect
consummate.example: The restoration of the ancient church was only consummated after a twenty years of labor.

contemptuous.definition: scornful, looking down at others with a sneering attitude
contemptuous.example: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.

contrite.example: Though he stole his little sister's licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.

conundrum.example: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

convivial.example: The wedding reception was convivial; friends who hadn't seen each other for ages drank and ate together before heading to the dance floor.

convoluted.example: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.

cornucopia.definition: an abundant supply of something good
cornucopia.example: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.

corroborate.definition: to confirm or lend support to (usually an idea or claim)
corroborate.example: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.

cosmopolitan.definition: comprising many cultures; global in reach and outlook
cosmopolitan.example: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.

credence.example: He placed no credence in psychics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.

creditable.definition: deserving of praise but not that amazing
creditable.example: Critics agreed the movie was creditable, but few gave it more than three out of five stars.

credulity.example: Virginia's wide-eyed credulity as a five-year old was replaced by suspicion after she learned that Santa Claus didn't really exist.

cumbersome.definition: difficult to handle or use especially because of size or weight
cumbersome.example: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books--these days we need only an e-reader.

dearth.example: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

debase.definition: reduce the quality or value of something
debase.example: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.

debunk.definition: expose as false ideas and claims, especially while ridiculing
debunk.example: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.

decimation.definition: destroying or killing a large part of the population
decimation.example: The decimation after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki is incomprehensible.

degrade.definition: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally
degrade.example: Jesse had mockingly pointed out all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.

delegate.example: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.

deliberate.definition: think about carefully; weigh the pros and cons of an issue
deliberate.example: Emergency situations such as this call for immediate action and leave no room to deliberate over options.

demean.definition: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect
demean.example: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.

demure.example: The portrait of her in a simple white blouse was sweet and demure.

deride.definition: treat or speak of with contempt
deride.example: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.

derisive.definition: abusing vocally; expressing contempt or ridicule
derisive.example: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.

derogative.definition: expressed as worthless or in negative terms
derogative.example: Never before have we seen a debate between two political candidates that was so derogative and filthy.

desecrate.definition: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place
desecrate.example: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.

destitute.example: Now that the mine is closed, the town is destitute of any economic activity.

deter.definition: try to prevent; show opposition to
deter.example: The government's primary job should invlove deterring paths to war, not finding ways to start them.

detrimental.definition: (sometimes followed by "to") causing harm or injury
detrimental.example: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.

devolve.example: The dialogue between the two academics devolved into a downright bitter argument.

diabolical.definition: to be extremely wicked like the devil
diabolical.example: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.

differentiate.definition: evolve so as to lead to a new species or develop in a way most suited to the
differentiate.example: Animals on Madagascar differentiated from other similar animal species due to many years of isolation on the island.

dilapidated.example: The main house has been restored but the gazebo is still dilapidated and unuseable.

diligent.definition: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks
diligent.example: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.

discord.example: Despite all their talented players, the team was filled with discord--some players refused to talk to others--and lost most of their games.

discreet.definition: careful to protect one's speech or actions in order to avoid offense or gain an
discreet.example: The professor thought that he was discreet, subtly wiping the stain off of his shirt, but as soon as he stepped off the podium a member of the audience pointed out the large ketchup stain.

discriminate.example: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.

disenfranchise.example: The U.S. Constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.

disheartened.example: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.

disparate.example: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

dispatch.definition: dispose of rapidly and without delay and efficiently
dispatch.example: As soon as the angry peasants stormed the castle, they caught the king and swiftly dispatched him.

docile.definition: easily handled or managed; willing to be taught or led or supervised or directed
docile.example: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.

dog.example: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.

dupe.definition: a person who is easily tricked or swindled
dupe.example: The charlatan mistook the crowd for a bunch of dupes, but the crowd was quickly on to him and decried his bald-faced attempt to bilk them.

eccentric.definition: highly unconventional or usual (usually describes a person)
eccentric.example: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.

egotist.example: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

eke.definition: To live off meager resources, to scrape by
eke.example: Stranded in a cabin over the winter, Terry was able to eke out an existence on canned food.

elaborate.example: Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.

elude.example: Even a basic understanding of physics can elude most high schools students.

elusive.definition: difficult to capture or difficult to remember
elusive.example: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.

embellish.definition: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.; make more beautiful
embellish.example: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.

embroiled.example: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal--a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.

empathetic.definition: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and
empathetic.example: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspitations and fears.

emulate.definition: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating; compete with successfully
emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.

endemic.definition: native; originating where it is found
endemic.example: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.

enmity.example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

entice.definition: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises
entice.example: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.

enumerate.example: I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

err.example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

errant.definition: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path
errant.example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.

erratic.example: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President's attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

euphoria.definition: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
euphoria.example: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.

evasive.example: Every time I call the bank, I receive the same evasive answers about our mortgage and never get a clear response.

evenhanded.example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

exasperate.example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

excruciating.example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

exemplify.definition: clarify by giving an example of
exemplify.example: Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.

exhort.example: Nelson's parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

extenuating.definition: making less guilty or more forgivable
extenuating.example: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.

facetious.example: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex eduation class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

fawn.definition: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.

ferret.example: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.

fete.example: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.
