fickle.definition: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments
fickle.example: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.

finagle.definition: achieve something by means of trickery or devious methods
finagle.example: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.

fledgling.definition: young and inexperienced; describing any new participant in some activity
fledgling.example: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.

fleece.example: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.

flounder.example: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has deal with taxes, she flounders.

flush.example: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

foible.definition: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
foible.example: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.

foolhardy.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
foolhardy.example: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.

forthright.definition: characterized by directness in manner or speech; without subtlety or evasion
forthright.example: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasent surprised by how forthright he was.

futile.definition: producing no result or effect; unproductive of success
futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.

genial.example: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

genteel.definition: marked by refinement in taste and manners
genteel.example: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.

glean.example: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.

glib.definition: (of a person) speaking with ease but without sincerity
glib.example: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.

goad.example: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.

grovel.example: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire.

guffaw.example: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

hamper.definition: prevent the progress or free movement of
hamper.example: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.

hamstrung.example: The FBI has made so many restriction on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

heyday.definition: the pinnacle or top of a time period or career
heyday.example: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.

hodgepodge.example: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

hound.example: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms--he even helped nab Al Capone.

humdrum.example: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.

illicit.definition: contrary to or forbidden by law
illicit.example: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.

immaterial.example: The judge found the defendant's comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

impeccable.example: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impede.definition: be a hindrance or obstacle to
impede.example: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.

impending.definition: close in time; about to occur
impending.example: The impending doom of our world has been a discussed and debated for 2000 years--maybe even longer.

impermeable.definition: does not allow fluids to pass through
impermeable.example: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.

implicate.definition: to indicate in wrongdoing, usually a crime
implicate.example: The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.

imponderable.definition: impossible to estimate or figure out
imponderable.example: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.

impregnable.definition: immune to attack; incapable of being tampered with
impregnable.example: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fotresses.

inadvertent.definition: happening by chance or unexpectedly or unintentionally
inadvertent.example: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led its the repeal.

inarticulate.definition: without or deprived of the use of speech or words
inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.

incense.example: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.

incessant.definition: uninterrupted in time and indefinitely long continuing
incessant.example: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.

inclement.definition: used of persons or behavior; showing no mercy
inclement.example: Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.

incumbent.definition: necessary (for someone) as a duty or responsibility
incumbent.example: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.

indict.definition: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing
indict.example: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.

indigenous.example: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S-- one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you're not dealing with an opossum.

indignant.definition: feeling anger over a perceived injustice

industrious.definition: characterized by hard work and perseverance
industrious.example: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.

inflammable.example: It only takes one person to leave an inflammable comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

ingenuity.example: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.

inkling.definition: a slight suggestion or vague understanding
inkling.example: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are structured.

insipid.example: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

insolvent.definition: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt
insolvent.example: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.

intermittent.definition: stopping and starting at irregular intervals
intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning--a surreal sleepless night.

inundate.example: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

irascible.example: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becames highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

irk.example: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

irresolute.definition: uncertain how to act or proceed
irresolute.example: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.

jargon.definition: a characteristic language of a particular group
jargon.example: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.

jocular.definition: characterized by jokes and good humor
jocular.example: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knock- knock jokes to anyone who would listen.

junta.definition: an aggressive takeover by a group (usually military)

laborious.definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort
laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.

leery.definition: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide
leery.example: Without checking his references and talking  to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

lucid.example: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

macabre.definition: suggesting the horror of death and decay; gruesome
macabre.example: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to--and often those moments after--a grisly death.

malady.example: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

malevolent.definition: wishing or appearing to wish evil to others; arising from intense ill will or hatred
malevolent.example: Villians are known for their malevolent nature, oftentimes inflicting cruetly on others just for enjoyment.

malleable.example: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes--the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

martial.example: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

maxim.definition: a short saying expressing a general truth
maxim.example: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300-page book to explain exactly what he means.

meander.example: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

melancholy.example: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

melee.definition: a wild, confusing fight or struggle
melee.example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.

mesmerize.example: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

misanthrope.example: Hamilton had been deceived so many times in his life that he hid behind the gruff exterior of a misanthrope, lambasting perfect strangers for no apparent reason.

miscreant.definition: a person who breaks the law
miscreant.example: Come back you miscreant! yelled the woman who just had her purse stollen.

miser.definition: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because they are greedy)
miser.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

misogynist.definition: a person who dislikes women in particular
misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.

moment.example: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton's writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.

moot.definition: open to argument or debate; undecidable in a meaningless or irrelevant way
moot.example: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committe might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.

morose.definition: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy
morose.example: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.

morph.definition: To undergo dramatic change in a seamless and barely noticeable fashion.
morph.example: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970's has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually standup and threaten to take swings at one another.

muted.example: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.

obdurate.definition: stubbornly persistent in changing an opinion or action
obdurate.example: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.

obliging.definition: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
obliging.example: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his "secret tips" on how to gain wealth and make friends.

obstinate.definition: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent
obstinate.example: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.

ornate.definition: marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details
ornate.example: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

paradoxical.definition: seemingly contradictory but nonetheless possibly true
paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.

pastoral.definition: relating to the countryside in a pleasant sense
pastoral.example: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of rural U.S. is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.

patronize.example: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.

paucity.example: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

peevish.example: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

perennial.definition: lasting an indefinitely long time; eternal; everlasting
perennial.example: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.

perpetuate.example: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

perquisite.definition: a right reserved exclusively by a particular person or group (especially a hereditary or
perquisite.example: Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.

pertinent.definition: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand
pertinent.example: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.

perturb.definition: disturb in mind or cause to be worried or alarmed
perturb.example: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illnesses, he no longer lets the little trivialities, such as late mail, perturb him.

peruse.example: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

pine.example: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.

pinnacle.example: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.

pithy.example: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.

pittance.example: Vinny's uncle beamed smugly about how he'd offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.

placid.example: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

plodding.example: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

ploy.definition: a clever plan to turn a situation to one's advantage
ploy.example: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.

powwow.example: Before the team takes the field, the coach always calls for a powwow so that he can make sure all the players are mentally in the right place.

precarious.example: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

precedent.definition: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time
precedent.example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.

preempt.definition: take the place of or have precedence over
preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.

preemptive.definition: done before someone else can do it
preemptive.example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.

presumption.definition: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to
presumption.example: The new neighbor quickly gained a reptuation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several of the neighbors homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.

presumptuous.example: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.example: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.

pristine.example: Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.

profuse.example: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

profusion.definition: the property of being extremely abundant
profusion.example: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

proponent.definition: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
proponent.example: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.

provisional.definition: under terms not final or fully worked out or agreed upon
provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.

pugnacious.definition: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative

qualm.definition: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
qualm.example: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he neverless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.

quandary.definition: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally
quandary.example: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.

raffish.definition: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
raffish.example: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.

raft.example: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.

rakish.definition: marked by a carefree unconventionality or disreputableness
rakish.example: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.

rankle.definition: gnaw into; make resentful or angry
rankle.example: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

rash.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences; imprudently incurring risk
rash.example: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nightime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.

redress.definition: an act of making something right
redress.example: Barry forgot his wife's birthday two years in a row, and was only able to redress his oversight by surprising his wife with a trip to Tahiti.

relegate.example: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

remiss.definition: to be negligent in one"s duty
remiss.example: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principle was relieved of his position after only three months.

renege.definition: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation
renege.example: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.

replete.definition: completely stocked or furnished with something
replete.example: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.

reprobate.definition: a person who is disapproved of
reprobate.example: Those old reprobates drinking all day down by the river--they are not going to amount to much.

reservation.definition: an unstated doubt that prevents you from accepting something wholeheartedly
reservation.example: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C.  but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.

resignation.definition: the acceptance of something unpleasant that can't be avoided
resignation.example: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.

resolve.definition: reach a conclusion after a discussion or deliberation
resolve.example: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.

respite.definition: a pause from doing something (as work)
respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.

retiring.definition: to be shy, and to be inclined to retract from company
retiring.example: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees--rather than mill about with "fashionable" folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.

retract.definition: pull inward or towards a center; formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief, usually
retract.example: Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.

rile.definition: cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations
rile.example: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

robust.definition: sturdy and strong in form, constitution, or construction
robust.example: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.

sanctimonious.definition: making a show of being pious; holier-than-thou
sanctimonious.example: Even during the quiet sanctity of evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.

sanguine.example: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

savvy.example: With his savvy business partner, the company was able to turn a profit within a year.

scintillating.definition: describes someone who is brilliant and lively
scintillating.example: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures--the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

screed.example: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government's deficiencies--only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

sentimental.definition: effusively or insincerely emotional, especially in art, music, and literature
sentimental.example: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas--overly sentimental.

serendipity.definition: the instance in which an accidental, fortunate discovery is made

serene.example: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

slapdash.example: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the faÃ§ade of the building.

smattering.definition: a slight or superficial understanding of a subject; a small amount of something
smattering.example: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.

smug.definition: marked by excessive complacency or self-satisfaction
smug.example: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.

snide.definition: expressive of contempt; derogatory or mocking in an indirect way
snide.example: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.

snub.definition: refuse to acknowledge; reject outright and bluntly
snub.example: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.

sordid.definition: involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt; foul
sordid.example: The nightly news simply announced that the senator had had an affair, but the tabloid published all the sordid details of the interaction.

spendthrift.example: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

spurn.example: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

squander.definition: spend thoughtlessly; waste time, money, or an opportunity
squander.example: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.

staid.example: Frank came from a staid enviroment, so he was shocked that his college rooommate sold narcotics.

start.definition: to suddenly move in a particular direction
start.example: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.

steadfast.definition: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable
steadfast.example: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.

stem.definition: to hold back or limit the flow or growth of something
stem.example: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.

stipend.example: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

stolid.definition: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; not easily aroused or excited
stolid.example: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.

stymie.definition: hinder or prevent the progress or accomplishment of
stymie.example: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make amlost no progress on the project.

summit.example: Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.

surly.definition: inclined to anger or bad feelings with overtones of menace
surly.example: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

tact.definition: consideration in dealing with others and avoiding giving offense
tact.example: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.

tarnish.definition: make dirty or spotty, as by exposure to air; also used metaphorically
tarnish.example: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.

tawdry.example: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.

taxing.example: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.

telling.definition: significant and revealing of another factor
telling.example: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

telltale.example: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

tender.example: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.

thoroughgoing.example: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

thrifty.example: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.definition: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
thwart.example: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

tirade.example: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

tout.definition: advertize in strongly positive terms; show off
tout.example: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research & Development division.

travail.definition: use of physical or mental energy; hard work; agony or anguish
travail.example: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.

tribulation.definition: something, especially an event, that causes difficulty and suffering
tribulation.example: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.

tumult.definition: a state of chaos, noise and confusion
tumult.example: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.

uncanny.definition: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences; surpassing the ordinary or
uncanny.example: Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

uncompromising.example: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.

unconscionable.example: The lawyer's demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

underwrite.example: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

unnerve.example: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly "Magoosh-ing", and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.

unprecedented.definition: having never been done or known before; novel
unprecedented.example: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.

unruly.definition: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to
unruly.example: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene--unless it's nap time.

unseemly.definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
unseemly.example: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.

urbane.definition: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social
urbane.example: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophistcate spy James Bond.

vacuous.definition: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance
vacuous.example: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.

vanquish.definition: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict
vanquish.example: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.

variance.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".

veneer.definition: covering consisting of a thin superficial layer that hides the underlying substance
veneer.example: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.

vicarious.definition: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of
vicarious.example: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can--through hundreds of intimate "tweets"--vicariously live the life of a famous person.

vie.example: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.

vindictive.definition: to have a very strong desire for revenge
vindictive.example: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.

virago.example: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago's invective--she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

voracious.definition: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto
voracious.example: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.

wanton.definition: without check or limitation; showing no moral restraints to one's anger, desire, or
wanton.example: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.

wax.definition: to gradually increase in size or intensity
wax.example: Her enthusiasm for the diva's new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.

whimsical.definition: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
whimsical.example: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.

zenith.example: At the zenith of his artistic career, Elvis was outselling any other artist on the charts.

abjure.definition: formally reject or give up (as a belief)
abjure.example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.

abrogate.example: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.

adjudicate.definition: to serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion
adjudicate.example: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.

afford.example: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.

alacrity.definition: an eager willingness to do something
alacrity.example: The first three weeks at his new job, Mark worked with such alacrity that upper management knew it would be giving him a promotion.

anachronism.definition: something that is inappropriate for the given time period (usually something old).
anachronism.example: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.

anathema.definition: a detested person; the source of somebody's hate
anathema.example: Hundreds of years ago, Galileo was anathema to the church; today the church is anathema to some on the left side of the political spectrum.

anemic.example: After three straight shows, the lead actress gave an anemic performance the fourth night, barely speaking loudly enough for those in the back rows to hear.

anodyne.example: Wilbur enjoyed a spicy Mexican breakfast, but Jill prefered a far more anodyne meal in the mornings.

antic.example: The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears.

aplomb.definition: great coolness and composure under strain
aplomb.example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.

apogee.example: The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart's music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.

apostate.definition: a person who has abandoned a religious faith or cause
apostate.example: An apostate of the Republican Party, Sheldon has yet to become affiliated with any party and dubs himself an independent.

apotheosis.definition: exaltation to divine status; the highest point of development
apotheosis.example: As difficult as it is to imagine, the apotheosis of Mark Zuckerberg's career, many believe, is yet to come.

approbatory.example: Although it might not be her best work, Hunter's new novel has received generally approbatory reviews.

appropriate.example: The committe appropriated the funds to its various members.

appurtenant.example: In hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

arch.example: The baroness was arch, making playful asides to the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious.

arrant.definition: complete and wholly (usually modifying a noun with negative connotation)
arrant.example: An arrant fool, Lawrence surprised nobody when he lost all his money in a pyramid scheme that was every bit as transparent as it was corrupt.

arriviste.definition: a person who has recently reached a position of power; a social climber
arriviste.example: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.

arrogate.example: Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink, and entertainment.

artifice.definition: cunning tricks used to deceive others
artifice.example: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.

artless.example: Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.

artlessness.example: I, personally, found the artlessness of her speech charming.

asperity.example: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.

assiduously.example: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

atavism.definition: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic; throwback
atavism.example: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.

attenuate.definition: to weaken (in terms of intensity); to taper off/become thinner.
attenuate.example: Her animosity towards Bob attenuated over the years, and she even went so far as to invite him to her party.

autocratic.definition: offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power
autocratic.example: The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.

baleful.definition: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
baleful.example: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.

base.definition: the lowest, class were without any moral principles
base.example: She was not so base as to begrudge the beggar the unwanted crumbs from her dinner plate.

bastardization.definition: an act that debases or corrupts
bastardization.example: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.

beg.example: By assuming that Charlie was headed to college--which he was not--Maggie begged the question when she asked him to which school he was headed in the Fall.

bemoan.definition: express discontent or a stong regret
bemoan.example: While the CFO carefully explained all the reasons for the cuts in benefits, after the meeting employees bemoaned the cuts as further evidence that management was against them.

benighted.definition: fallen into a state of ignorance
benighted.example: Far from being a period of utter benightedness, The Medieval Ages produced some great works of theological speculation.

bereft.example: You are not bereft if you haven't played on your Xbox in the past week, his mother said.

besotted.example: Never before have I seen my mom so besotted, and honestly, I hope it's the last time she drinks so much.

bilious.example: Rex was bilious all morning, and his face would only take on a look of contentedness when he'd had his morning cup of coffee.

blinkered.definition: to have a limited outlook or understanding
blinkered.example: In gambling, the addict is easily blinkered by past successes and/or past failures, forgetting that the outcome of any one game is independent of the games that preceded it.

bowdlerize.definition: edit by omitting or modifying parts considered indelicate
bowdlerize.example: To recieve an R rating, the entire movie was bowdlerized because it contained so much violence and grotesque subject matter.

bridle.example: The hostess bridled at the tactless dinner guests who insisted on eating before everybody had gotten their food.

bristle.definition: react in an offended or angry manner
bristle.example: As we discussed the painting, I noticed the artitst's wife bristling at our criticisms, ready to defend her husband's work.

broadside.example: Political broadsides are usually strongest in the weeks leading up to a national election.

brook.definition: put up with something or somebody unpleasant
brook.example: While she was at the chalkboard, the teacher did not brook any form of talking--even a tiny peep resulted in afternoon detention.

browbeat.definition: be bossy towards; discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner
browbeat.example: During the interrogation, the suspect was browbeaten into signing a false confession.

byzantine.example: Getting a driver's license is not simply a matter of taking a test; the regulations and procedures are so byzantine that many have found themselves at the mercy of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

callow.example: Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.

canard.example: The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.

capitulate.example: Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.

cataclysm.definition: an event resulting in great loss and misfortune
cataclysm.example: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.

catholic.example: Jonah's friends said that Jonah's taste in music was eclectic; Jonah was quick to point out that not only was his taste eclectic but it was also catholic: he enjoyed music from countries as far-flung as Mali and Mongolia.

cede.example: Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing childrens' educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.

celerity.example: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

chagrin.definition: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of
chagrin.example: She never cared what others said about her appearance but was chagrined by the smallest comment from her mother.

charlatan.definition: a flamboyant deceiver; one who attracts customers with tricks or jokes
charlatan.example: You may call him a "motivational speaker," but I call him a charlatan--he doesn't have any idea what he's really talking about.

chary.example: Jack was wary of GRE words that looked similar, because they usually had different definitions; not so with chary, a word that he began to use interchangeably with wary.

chauvinism.definition: fanatical patriotism; belief that one's group/cause is superior to all other
chauvinism.example: Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do.

chimera.definition: something desired or wished for but is only an illusion and impossible to achieve
chimera.example: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera--a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendancies.

choleric.definition: prone to outbursts of temper; easily angered
choleric.example: While a brilliant lecturer, Mr. Dawson came across as choleric and unapproachable--very rarely did students come to his office hours.

churlish.example: The manager was unnecessarily churlish to his subordinates, rarely deigning to say hello, but always quick with a sartorial jab if someone happened to be wearing anything even slightly mismatching.

complaisant.definition: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
complaisant.example: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employee and anticipating future requests.

complicit.definition: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable
complicit.example: While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.

conciliate.example: His opponents believed his gesture to be conciliatory, yet as soon as they put down their weapons, he unsheathed a hidden sword.

concomitant.definition: describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in
concomitant.example: Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.

conflagration.definition: a very intense and uncontrolled fire
conflagration.example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, do to the heat and lack of rain.

conflate.definition: mix together different elements or concepts
conflate.example: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.

contentious.example: Since old grandpa Harry became very contentious during the summer when only reruns were on T.V., the grandkids learned to hide from him at every opportunity.

corollary.definition: a practical consequence that follows naturally
corollary.example: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.

cosseted.example: The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

coterminous.definition: being of equal extent or scope or duration
coterminous.example: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.

countermand.definition: a contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command
countermand.example: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.

crestfallen.example: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

crystallize.definition: cause to take on a definite and clear shape
crystallize.example: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.

cupidity.example: Some believe people that amassing as much wealth as possible is the meaning to life--yet they often realize that cupidity brings anything but happiness.

curmudgeon.example: Since Uncle Mike was the family curmudgeon, each Thanksgiving he was plied with copious amounts of wine, in the hope that she would become less grouchy.

debonair.example: James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets, and debonair manner.

decry.example: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

defray.definition: to help pay the cost of, either in part of full
defray.example: In order for Sean to attend the prestigious college, his generous uncle helped defray the excessive tuition with a monthly donation.

deign.definition: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity
deign.example: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.

demonstrative.definition: given to or marked by the open expression of emotion
demonstrative.example: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.

denouement.definition: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the
denouement.example: At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.

derelict.example: At one time the waterfront factories were busy and productive, but now they stand derelict and will be torn down.

desiccated.example: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books.

desideratum.example: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.

despot.example: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.

diatribe.definition: a strong verbal attack against a person or institution
diatribe.example: Steve's mom launched into a diatribe during the PTA meeting, contending that the school was little more than a daycare in which students stare at the wall and teachers stare at the chalkboard.

diminutive.example: When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.

disabuse.definition: to persuade somebody that his/her belief is not valid
disabuse.example: As a child, I was quickly disabused of the notion that Santa Claus was a rotund benefactor of infinite largess--one night I saw my mother diligently wrapping presents and storing them under our Christmas tree.

discursive.definition: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point
discursive.example: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.

disingenuous.definition: not straightforward; giving a false appearance of frankness
disingenuous.example: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.

dispensation.definition: an exemption from a rule or obligation
dispensation.example: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.

dissemble.definition: conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit
dissemble.example: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.

dissipate.example: Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.

dissolution.definition: a living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure
dissolution.example: Many Roman emporers were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.

doleful.example: No event is more doleful than the passing of my mother; she was a shining star in my life, and it brings me great sadness to think that she is now gone.

dolorous.example: Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.

doughty.example: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

dovetail.definition: fit together tightly, as if by means of a interlocking joint
dovetail.example: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail each other very well.

duplicity.definition: deceitfulness, pretending to want one thing but interested in something else
duplicity.example: A life of espionage is one of duplicity: an agent must pretend to be a totally different person than who she or he actually is.

ebullient.example: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

effervescent.definition: marked by high spirits or excitement
effervescent.example: After the sales result, the manager was in an effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work early that day.

effrontery.definition: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to
effrontery.example: The skateboarders acted with effrontery, skating through the church grounds and spray-painting signs warning trespassers.

elegiac.example: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

embryonic.definition: in an early stage of development
embryonic.example: The Board of Directors is hoping to launch a new product soon, but planning for the Z7 is in an embryonic stages.

empiricism.definition: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science
empiricism.example: Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.

enamor.example: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.

encumber.example: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

enjoin.definition: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority
enjoin.example: The government agency enjoined the chemical company to clean up the hazardous dump it had created over the years.

enormity.example: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words--within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.

enthrall.example: She was so enthralled by the movie that she never heard people screaming, "Fire! Fire!" in the neighboring theater.

epiphany.definition: a sudden revelation or moment of insight
epiphany.example: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he prompty quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.

eponym.definition: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is
eponym.example: Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.

equitable.definition: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience
equitable.example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting--at least until the ice cream is gone.

equivocate.definition: to speak vaguely, usually with the intention to mislead or deceive
equivocate.example: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.

ersatz.example: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelley found highly inflated.

estimable.example: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.

ethereal.example: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

evanescent.example: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time--an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.

excoriate.example: Entrusted with the prototype to his company's latest smartphone, Larry, during a late night karaoke bout, let the prototype slip into the hands of a rival company--the next day Larry was excoriated, and then fired.

execrate.example: Though the new sitcom did decently in the ratings, Nelson railed against the show, saying that it was nothing more than an execrable pastiche of tired clichÃ©'s and canned laughter.

exegesis.definition: critical explanation or analysis, especially of a text
exegesis.example: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis--over the past five centuries there have been as many interpretations as there are pages in the Old Testament.

exemplar.example: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat, and thoughtful work.

exiguity.example: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

exorbitant.definition: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
exorbitant.example: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.

expansive.definition: communicative, and prone to talking in a sociable manner
expansive.example: After a few sips of cognac, the octogenarian shed his irascible demeanor and became expansive, speaking fondly of the "good old days".

expunge.example: When I turned 18, all of the shoplifting and jaywalking charges were expunged from my criminal record.

expurgate.example: The censor expurgated every reference to sex and drugs, converting the rapper's raunchy flow into a series of bleeps.

extrapolate.definition: draw from specific cases for more general cases
extrapolate.example: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.

facile.definition: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth
facile.example: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.

factious.definition: produced by, or characterized by internal dissension

feckless.example: Two years after graduation, Charlie still lived with his parents and had no job, becoming more feckless with each passing day.

fecund.example: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

fell.example: For fans of the Harry Potter series, the fell Lord Voldemort, who terrorized poor Harry for seven lengthy installments, has finally been vanquished by the forces of good--unless, that is, JK Rowling decides to come out of retirement.

firebrand.example: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.

flag.definition: droop, sink, or settle from or as if from pressure or loss of tautness; become less intense
flag.example: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.

flippant.example: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

flummox.definition: be a mystery or bewildering to
flummox.example: Mary's behavoir completely flummoxes me: I never have any idea what her motivations might be.

fractious.definition: irritable and is likely to cause disruption
fractious.example: We rarely invite my fractious Uncle over for dinner; he always complains about the food, and usually launches into a tirade on some touchy subject.

gaffe.definition: a socially awkward or tactless act
gaffe.example: In a famous gaffe, Vice President Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.

gambit.definition: a manuveur or risk in a game or conversation, designed to secure an advantage
gambit.example: Randy played a gambit, telling his boss that he would leave at the end of the week if he didn't get a raise.

gerrymander.definition: to manipulate voting districts in order to favor a particular political party
gerrymander.example: Years ago, savvy politicians had gerrymandered the city center to ensure their re-election.

graft.example: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.

grandiloquent.example: The dictator was known for his grandiloquent speeches, puffing his chest out and using big, important- sounding words.

gumption.example: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the U.S. during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

hagiographic.definition: excessively flattering toward someone's life or work
hagiographic.example: Most accounts of Tiger Woods life were hagiographic, until, that is, his affairs made headlines.

hail.example: Many college superstar athletes are hailed as the next big thing, but then flop at the professional level.

halcyon.definition: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and
halcyon.example: The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.

hauteur.definition: overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors
hauteur.example: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice begin displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.

hector.example: The boss's hectoring manner put off many employees, some of whom quit as soon as they found new jobs.

hedge.definition: to limit or qualify a statement; to avoid making a direct statement
hedge.example: When asked why he had decided to buy millions of shares at the very moment the tech companies stock soared, the CEO hedged, mentioning something vague about gut instinct.

histrionic.example: Though she received a B- on the test, she had such a histrionic outburst that one would have thought that she'd been handed a death sentence.

hoary.example: Most workout gurus are young, fit people, whereas most yoga gurus are hoary men with long white beards.

hobble.definition: to hold back  the progress of something
hobble.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.

hoodwink.example: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

hubris.example: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

illustrious.definition: widely known and esteemed; having or conferring glory
illustrious.example: Einstein was possibly the most illustrious scientist in recent history.

imbibe.definition: to drink or absorb as if drinking
imbibe.example: Plato imbibed Socrates' teachings to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.

imbroglio.definition: a confusing and potentially embarrassing situation
imbroglio.example: The chef cook-off featured one gourmand who had the unfortunate distinction of mixing the wrong broths, creating an imbroglio that diners would not soon forget.

immure.example: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.

impecunious.example: In extremely trying times, even the moderately wealthy, after a few turns of ill-fortune, can become impecunious.

imperious.definition: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as
imperious.example: Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.

impervious.definition: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
impervious.example: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.

impetuous.definition: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
impetuous.example: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.

importuned.example: After weeks of importuning the star to meet for a five-minute interview, the journalist finally got what she wanted.

improvident.example: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

impugn.example: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the is idea taken as truth.

impute.example: He imputed his subpar performance on the test to a combination of stress and poor sleep.

inanity.definition: total lack of meaning or ideas
inanity.example: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.

inchoate.definition: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
inchoate.example: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the Middle Ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.

incontrovertible.definition: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove
incontrovertible.example: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.

indigent.example: The indigents, huddled under the overpass, tried to start a small bonfire in the hope of staying warm.

ineffable.definition: too sacred to be uttered; defying expression or description
ineffable.example: While art critics can occasionally pinpoint a work's greatness, much of why a piece captures our imaginations is completely ineffable.

ineluctable.example: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.

inequity.definition: injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards
inequity.example: After decades of racial inequity, the "separate but equal" doctrine was successfully overturned.

infelicitous.example: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

inimitable.example: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

insouciance.example: Surprisingly, Hank had become a high-powered CEO; his high school friends remembered him as "Hanky Panky", who shrugged off each failed class with insouciance.

insufferable.example: Chester always tried to find some area in which he excelled above others; unsurprisingly, his co-workers found him insufferable and chose to exclude him from daily luncheons out.

internecine.definition: (of conflict) within a group or organization
internecine.example: The guerilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.

intimation.example: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

inure.definition: to make accustomed to something unpleasant
inure.example: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.

invective.example: The Internet has unleashed the invectives in many of us; many people post stinging criticism on the comments section underneath newspaper articles or YouTube videos.

invidious.example: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.

inviolable.definition: never to be broken, infringed, or dishonored
inviolable.example: Too many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.

inviolate.example: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.

irrefutable.example: The existence of life on earth is irrefutable; the existence of intelligent life on earth is still hotly debated.

jaundice.definition: to be biased against due to envy or prejudice
jaundice.example: Shelly was jaundiced towards Olivia; though the two had once been best friends, Olivia had become class president, prom queen, and, to make matters worse, the girlfriend of the one boy Shelly liked.

jejune.example: Her boss further cemented his reuptation for being jejune after throwing a fit when the water cooler wasn't refilled.

jingoist.definition: a person who thinks that their country should be at war

juggernaut.definition: a force that cannot be stopped
juggernaut.example: Napoleon was considered a juggernaut until he decided to invade Russia in winter; after which, his once indomitable army was decimated by cold and famine.

kowtow.definition: to bow or act in a subservient manner
kowtow.example: Paul kowtowed to his boss so often the boss herself became nauseated by his sycophancy.

lacerate.definition: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress
lacerate.example: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.

lachrymose.example: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

lampoon.example: Mark Twain understood that lampooning a bad idea with humor was the most effective criticism.

languish.example: Stranded in the wilderness for four days, the hiker languished, eating protein bars and nuts.

lascivious.example: Lolita is a challenging novel for many, not necessarily because of the elevated prose style but because of the depravity of the main character, Humbert Humbert, who, as an old, lascivious man, falls in love with a girl.

limpid.example: Her limpid prose made even the most recondite subjects accessible to all.

litany.definition: any long and tedious account of something
litany.example: Mr. Rogers spoke to a Senate committee and did not give a litany of reasons to keep funding the program, but instead, appealed to the basic human decency of all present.

loath.definition: unwillingness to do something contrary to your custom (usually followed by 'to')
loath.example: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.

lugubrious.example: At the funeral, lugubrious songs filled the small church.

machinate.definition: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together
machinate.example: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.

magisterial.definition: offensively self-assured or given to exercising unwarranted power
magisterial.example: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.

malapropism.definition: the confusion of a word with another word that sounds similar
malapropism.example: Whenever I looked glum, my mother would offer to share "an amusing antidote" with me--an endearing malapropism of "anecdote" that never failed to cheer me up.

malfeasance.definition: misconduct or wrongdoing (especially by a public official)
malfeasance.example: Not even the mayor's trademark pearly-toothed grin could save him from charges of malfeasance: while in power, he'd been running an illegal gambling rink in the room behind his office.

malingerer.definition: someone shirking their duty by pretending to be sick or incapacitated
malingerer.example: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.

martinet.example: The job seemed perfect to Rebecca, until she found out that her boss was a total martinet; after each project the boss would come by to scrutinize--and inevitably criticize--every little detail of the work Rebecca had done.

maunder.definition: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly
maunder.example: After drinking two expressos each, the animated couple would maunder loudly, annoying the other patrons in the coffee shop.

mellifluous.example: Chelsea's grandmother thought Franz Schubert's music to be the most mellifluous ever written; Chelsea demurred, and to her grandmother's chagrin, would blast Rihanna on the home stereo speakers.

mendicant.definition: a pauper who lives by begging
mendicant.example: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.

meteoric.definition: like a meteor in speed or brilliance or transience
meteoric.example: The early spectacular successes propelled the pitcher to meteoric stardom, but a terribly injury tragically cut short his career.

mettlesome.example: For its raid on the Bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad, Seal Team Six has become, for many Americans, the embodiment of mettle.

misattribute.definition: To erroneously attribute; to falsely ascribe; used especially of authorship.
misattribute.example: I made a mistake; I misattributed "Crime and Punishment" to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.

modicum.definition: a small or moderate or token amount
modicum.example: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.

mordant.definition: biting and caustic in thought, manner, or style
mordant.example: While Phil frequently made mordant remarks about company policy overall, he always was considerably gentler in discussing any person in particular.

moribund.definition: being on the point of death; declining rapidly losing all momentum in progress
moribund.example: Whether you like it or not, jazz as a genre is moribund at best, possibly already dead.

mulct.example: The so-called magical diet cure simply ended up mulcting Maria out of hundreds of dollars, but did nothing for her weight.

nadir.example: For many pop music fans, the rap and alternative-rock dominated 90s were the nadir of musical expression.

nettlesome.example: Maria found her coworkers cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

noisome.example: Each August, when the winds moved in a south easterly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.

nonchalant.example: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.

objurgate.example: The manager spent an hour objurgating the employee in the hopes that he would not make these mistakes again.

oblique.example: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.

obstreperous.definition: noisily and stubbornly defiant; willfully difficult to control
obstreperous.example: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.

obtain.example: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.

obtuse.definition: slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking in insight or
obtuse.example: Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.

officious.definition: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
officious.example: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.

ossify.definition: make rigid and set into a conventional pattern
ossify.example: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.

overweening.example: Mark was so convinced of his basketball skills that in his overweening pride he could not fathom that his name was not on the varsity list; he walked up to the basketball coach and told her she had forgotten to add his name.

palatable.definition: acceptable to the taste or mind
palatable.example: MIkey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.

palaver.definition: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly
palaver.example: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.

palimpsest.definition: something that has been changed numerous times but on which traces of former
palimpsest.example: The downtown was a palimpsest of the city's checkered past: a new Starbucks had opened up next to an abandoned, shuttered building, and a freshly asphalted road was inches away from a pothole large enough to swallow a small dog.
